TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit UpDownBase extends System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl
Public MustInherit Class UpDownBase Inherits ContainerControl
public ref class UpDownBase abstract : System::Windows::Forms::ContainerControl

Docs.summary: Implements the basic functionality required by a spin box (also known as an up-down control).

remarks.format:
## Remarks A spin box consists of a text box and a small vertical scroll bar, commonly referred to as a spin button control. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase> class links the two controls and allows the user to change the display in the text box by clicking the up or down buttons or by entering the appropriate type of value directly into the text box. Use the spin box in cases where you want to limit the list of values a user can select, similar to a list box or combo box. Depending upon the type of list you want to display, the advantage to using a spin box is that it allows you to quickly set a range of valid values, rather than adding items one at a time. Implementing a spin box requires less data validation than a text box, as you can limit the data type when you derive a class from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. An example of this is the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> class, which limits the values to the numeric type and uses a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown.Maximum%2A> property to validate the data.
To allow the user to use the arrow keys to change the contents of a spin box, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.InterceptArrowKeys%2A> property to `true`. To restrict the user to values you specify, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ReadOnly%2A> property to `true`. To control the alignment of text in the spin box, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.TextAlign%2A> property. To set the alignment of the up and down buttons in relation to the text box portion of the control, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UpDownAlign%2A> property to either <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LeftRightAlignment.Left> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LeftRightAlignment.Right>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UpButton%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.DownButton%2A> methods, when overridden, handle the clicking of the up or down buttons. When overridden, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ValidateEditText%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UpdateEditText%2A> methods validate the value (either selected or entered) and update the text displayed in the spin box. If the value fails validation, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Select%2A> method to select the text that is not valid. This allows the user to quickly correct the text by simply typing in a new value without having to manually select or delete the existing text.
Starting with the .NET Framework 4.6, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase> control will be resized based on the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry:
``` <appSettings> <add key="EnableWindowsFormsHighDpiAutoResizing" value="true" /> </appSettings>
```
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> and sets some of its properties derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. This code requires that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control named `numericUpDown1`, two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls named `comboBox1` and `comboBox2`, and three <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls named `checkBox1`, `checkBox2`, and `checkBox2` created on a form. Add the following items to `comboBox1`: `None`, `Fixed3D`, and `FixedSingle`. Add the following items to `comboBox2`: `Left`, `Right`, and `Center`.
The code allows you to change the property values at run time and see how each affects the appearance and behavior of the spin box.
[!code-cpp[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

block.para: When you inherit from , you must override the following members: , , , and .

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.AutoSizeChanged> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of a type that inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>, such as a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DomainUpDown>. Then name the instance `UpDownBase1` and ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.AutoSizeChanged> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#380](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#380)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#380](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#380)]

## Remarks You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBoxBase.BorderStyle%2A> property to create borderless and flat controls in addition to the default three-dimensional control.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> and sets some of its properties derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. This code requires that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control named `numericUpDown1`, two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls named `comboBox1` and `comboBox2`, and three <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls named `checkBox1`, `checkBox2`, and `checkBox2` created on a form. Add the following items to `comboBox1`: `None`, `Fixed3D`, and `FixedSingle`. Add the following items to `comboBox2`: `Left`, `Right`, and `Center`.
The code allows you to change the property values at run time and see how each affects the appearance and behavior of the spin box.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the text property is being changed internally by its parent class.
Docs.value: if the property is being changed internally by the class; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ChangingText%2A> property acts as a flag for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase> class. This property is used by derived classes to indicate when the class is changing the current <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> property internally. If this property is set to `false`, the control requires that the user is changing the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> property and will set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UserEdit%2A> property to `true`.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can use the UP ARROW and DOWN ARROW keys to select values.
Docs.value: if the control allows the use of the UP ARROW and DOWN ARROW keys to select values; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.InterceptArrowKeys%2A> property is set to `true` and the spin box (also known as an up-down control) has focus, the user can use the UP ARROW and DOWN ARROW keys to select values.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> and sets some of its properties derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. This code requires that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control named `numericUpDown1`, two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls named `comboBox1` and `comboBox2`, and three <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls named `checkBox1`, `checkBox2`, and `checkBox2` created on a form. Add the following items to `comboBox1`: `None`, `Fixed3D`, and `FixedSingle`. Add the following items to `comboBox2`: `Left`, `Right`, and `Center`.
The code allows you to change the property values at run time and see how each affects the appearance and behavior of the spin box.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.OnFontChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.OnMouseDown%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: public int PreferredHeight { get; }
.property instance int32 PreferredHeight
Public ReadOnly Property PreferredHeight As Integer
public: property int PreferredHeight { int get(); };
member this.PreferredHeight : int

Docs.summary: Gets the height of the spin box (also known as an up-down control).
Docs.value: The height, in pixels, of the spin box.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.PreferredHeight%2A> property value is based on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBoxBase.PreferredHeight%2A> property of the text box portion of the control and is adjusted for the style of border.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> and sets some of its properties derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. This code requires that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls, and three <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls created on a form. Label the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.BorderStyle%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.TextAlign%2A>. Label the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.InterceptArrowKeys%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ReadOnly%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UpDownAlign%2A>. The code allows you to change the property values at run time and see how each affects the appearance and behavior of the spin box. Add the following items to the combo box labeled BorderStyle: `None`, `Fixed3D`, and `FixedSingle`. Add the following items to the combo box labeled TextAlign: `Left`, `Right`, and `Center`.
[!code-cpp[Classic UpDownBase.BorderStyle Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.BorderStyle Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic UpDownBase.BorderStyle Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.BorderStyle Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic UpDownBase.BorderStyle Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.BorderStyle Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public bool ReadOnly { get; set; }
.property instance bool ReadOnly
Public Property ReadOnly As Boolean
public: property bool ReadOnly { bool get(); void set(bool value); };
member this.ReadOnly : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the text can be changed by the use of the up or down buttons only.
Docs.value: if the text can be changed by the use of the up or down buttons only; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks By setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ReadOnly%2A> property to `true`, you will eliminate the need for much validation of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> property. The user will be restricted to the use of the up and down buttons to change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> values. It will only allow them to select values you specify.
> [!NOTE] > In the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DomainUpDown>, the behavior described is slightly different. When <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ReadOnly%2A> is set to `true` and a key is pressed, the control selects the first item in the collection where the first character matches the key pressed.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> and sets some of its properties derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. This code requires that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls, and three <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls created on a form. Label the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.BorderStyle%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.TextAlign%2A>. Label the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.InterceptArrowKeys%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ReadOnly%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UpDownAlign%2A>. The code allows you to change the property values at run time and see how each affects the appearance and behavior of the spin box. Add the following items to the combo box labeled BorderStyle: `None`, `Fixed3D`, and `FixedSingle`. Add the following items to the combo box labeled TextAlign: `Left`, `Right`, and `Center`.
[!code-cpp[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Select (int start, int length);
.method public hidebysig instance void Select(int32 start, int32 length) cil managed
Public Sub Select (start As Integer, length As Integer)
public: void Select(int start, int length);
override this.Select : int * int -> unit

Docs.param: The position of the first character to be selected.
The total number of characters to be selected.
Docs.summary: Selects a range of text in the spin box (also known as an up-down control) specifying the starting position and number of characters to select.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Select%2A> method can be used when the spin box gets focus, or when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> property fails data validation. When adding the validation code for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ValidateEditText%2A> method in a derived class, call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Select%2A> method when validation fails.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown>. This code requires that a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> have been created on a form and the <xref:System.Drawing> namespace has been added as a reference. On the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event for the button, the point size of text in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control increases. This prompts the control to adjust its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.PreferredHeight%2A> property so that all the text is visible in the control. After the user enters a new value and leaves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, the text is converted to a numeric value from a string value and validated to be between the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown.Maximum%2A> values. If the value is not valid, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox> is displayed with the error, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Select%2A> method will select the text so the user can enter a new value.
[!code-cpp[Classic UpDownBase.Text Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.Text Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic UpDownBase.Text Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.Text Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic UpDownBase.Text Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.Text Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

member this.Text : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text displayed in the spin box (also known as an up-down control).
Docs.value: The string value displayed in the spin box.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UpdateEditText%2A> method is called if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> property is set while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UserEdit%2A> property is set to `true`. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.ValidateEditText%2A> method is called if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text%2A> property is set while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.UserEdit%2A> property is set to `false`.
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown>. This code requires that a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> have been created on a form and the <xref:System.Drawing> namespace has been added as a reference. On the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event for the button, the point size of text in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control increases. This prompts the control to adjust its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.PreferredHeight%2A> property so all the text is visible in the control. After the user enters a new value and leaves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control, the text is converted to a numeric value from a string value and validated to be between the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown.Minimum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown.Maximum%2A> values. If the value is not valid, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox> is displayed with the error, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Select%2A> method will select the text so the user can enter a new value.
[!code-cpp[Classic UpDownBase.Text Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.Text Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic UpDownBase.Text Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.Text Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic UpDownBase.Text Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase.Text Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example uses the derived class <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> and sets some of its properties derived from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase>. This code requires that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NumericUpDown> control named `numericUpDown1`, two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> controls named `comboBox1` and `comboBox2`, and three <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> controls named `checkBox1`, `checkBox2`, and `checkBox2` created on a form. Add the following items to `comboBox1`: `None`, `Fixed3D`, and `FixedSingle`. Add the following items to `comboBox2`: `Left`, `Right`, and `Center`.
The code allows you to change the property values at run time and see how each affects the appearance and behavior of the spin box.
[!code-cpp[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic UpDownBase Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic UpDownBase Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

Docs.summary: When overridden in a derived class, validates the text displayed in the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

remarks.format: ## Remarks Some examples of validation include comparing the text entered to the data type set in your derived class, comparing the text to a list of values, or verifying the text to be within a range of values.

block.para: When overriding this method in a derived class, be sure to add code in this method to validate the text of the spin box. This method will be called if the property is set to when the property is set.
